newsitem.title: ROMANIA: CLINTON'S NATO SPEECH ON ROMANIAN FOREIGN MINISTRY AGENDA.
newsitem.headline: CLINTON'S NATO SPEECH ON ROMANIAN FOREIGN MINISTRY AGENDA.

text.p: Romania praised U.S. President Bill Clinton's speech setting 1999 as the target date for NATO to bring in some former Soviet bloc states, a foreign ministry official said on Wednesday.

"The statement sets for the first time a clear and open perspective for all emerging democracies willing and prepared to join the Western defence alliance," foreign ministry spokesman Sorin Ducaru told a news conference.
Ducaru said Romania was counting on the United States as well as on other NATO member-countries to support its bid to join the alliance in a first wave of enlargement.
Romanian President Ion Iliescu sent messages to leaders of the 16-member alliance, urging them to consider the Balkan country for fast-track admission.
Other items on Wednesday's agenda included:

- Romanian and Ukrainian foreign ministry experts to meet in Kiev over October 26-29 to discuss boosting ties and to prepare resumption of negotiations on bilateral treaty. -- Bucharest Newsroom 40-1 3120264
